captions.text: *INTRO MUSIC*
Let&#39;s face it, Sony, you and I haven&#39;t been seeing eye to eye lately.
You refused to give us a Ratchet and Clank review code,
I called you out on the video, you didn&#39;t send us a
Horizon Forbidden West code before launch day,
I came over and pissed through your cat flap,
but I want you to know that I believe maintaining my
journalistic integrity is more important than keeping up
a petty one-sided feud.
I say that to disabuse any notion of bias
being attached to the following statement:
I hate Horizon: Forbidden West and I hate you.
Bit confusing, actually. Horizon Forbidden West
doesn&#39;t feel that much different to the first one
and I don&#39;t remember getting a hate boner for that.
Truth be told, I don&#39;t remember very much about it at all.
I went back and watched my review of it for a refresher
and my past self was actually vaguely positive.
Certainly no mention of the main character
being a total fucking charisma vacuum who
only ever talks in a breathy monotone constantly...
pausing like she&#39;s trying to... work out a...
kidney stone making her voice performance
the aural equivalent of Chinese water torture.
Maybe it&#39;s my ever solidifying antipathy towards
the standard Jiminy Cockthroat model for triple-A open world games.
Maybe Elden Ring spoiled me.
Maybe I&#39;m just in a bad mood from the way a cat flap
recently snapped shut on my bellend.
I did extract some amusement from the way all the characters are
dressed like an abandoned farmer&#39;s market in a high graffiti
neighbourhood and then in conversation just awkwardly stand
around sweating under ridiculous headdresses, fidgeting and
mumbling like a bunch of teenagers chatting outside a cinema
where none of them want to be the one to suggest they go home
&#39;cos it&#39;s a school night. Anyway, back in the post-reboot
mumblecore future of Horizon, Aloy, having spent the last game
learning how to transcend her outcast status and learn to work
with other people, promptly chucks all of that development in the
bin so fast it makes the lid spin around. When it transpires that all
the shit she did in the last game to save the world didn&#39;t actually
save it properly and she has to journey to the titular forbidden
west to save it for realsies, she is fucking chomping at the bit to
get away from everyone she knows. Oh but don&#39;t you see it&#39;s too
dangerous for them. She is the only one who can shoulder the
burden of saving the world, and it&#39;s not like anyone else has an
investment in helping her succeed in that goal. What a selfish
fucking bint.
Aloy comes across like she holds everyone who doesn&#39;t have her
old world technology cheat sheet in total eye-rolling contempt.
Whenever questgivers are telling her the problem, she&#39;s like a
disgruntled computer science teacher&#39;s assistant watching an old
person type. &quot;Urgh, get out of the way, I&#39;LL do it.&quot; It&#39;s the classic
problem of an overly competent protagonist who&#39;s already had
their character development wedged into the middle of the story
like a fucking unmoving tree trunk with half the charisma. But
here&#39;s the punchline that makes it twice as obnoxious: she&#39;s not
actually competent. Or at least she doesn&#39;t come across as such
in gameplay. She swans about the cutscenes going &quot;Yeah no
worries I&#39;ll just go overcome the current adversity in my unflinching
ginger finery, want me to pick you up some baby wipes while I&#39;m
out?&quot;, and then she runs out into yet another fight with robot
dinosaurs and gets screamingly batted back and forth between
two giant metal Thagomizers for five minutes. While having to
constantly scarf down healing berries like a Sony QA tester with a
bottle of caffeine pills.
At least she does when I&#39;m controlling her. I was a bit underlevelled
&#39;cos I was trying to rush through critical path for the review. I did
try a few random sidequests but all of them were variations on
&quot;Oh please rescue my close friend stroke family member who went
alone to confront a robot stroke group of bandits in order to
prove themselves and didn&#39;t realise you need protagonist status
to get away with shit like that.&quot; So direct combat with robots was
mostly me getting nine tenths of my health blasted off by an
unexpected tail whip or missile barrage and having to frantically
roly-poly into cover to suck down three acai smoothies. But I can
only assume that&#39;s how it&#39;s supposed to go because all the combat
areas are absolutely carpeted in berries. It&#39;s like the haemhorroid
ward synchronized swimming team out there. Oh no I&#39;m out of
berries. &quot;Don&#39;t worry! Just press a button to refill your berry pouch
from your stash!&quot; Well what&#39;s the point of even having a fucking
stash mechanic if we can just teleport stuff out of it whenever?
Are we trying to smuggle shit through airport customs? Oh no I&#39;m
out of berries for real. Not to worry, there&#39;s a small health potion in
my consumable quick select, just have to scroll through to find it.
Trap, trap, trap, stamina potion, trap, medium health po - I haven&#39;t
got any medium health potions, why is the icon still cluttering up
the fucking quick sele - oh, I just got thagomizered again. See, this
is what&#39;s driving me nuts about Jiminy Cockthroat games - always
bloated with game mechanics layering over each over and
getting in the way, none of them with enough focus to provide a
solid core to the experience. It&#39;s like trying to appreciate your
spouse&#39;s naughty underwear while they&#39;re also wearing baggy
pyjamas and a sou-wester and the back half of a pantomime
horse. Go to the upgrade menu and the game proudly unfurls
multiple distinct gameplay styles with separate upgrade trees -
warrior, trapper, hunter, dozy, beaky, mick and titch - but on
closer inspection half the upgrades feel kinda inconsequential -
add 30% damage to ranged combat while critically low on health
as long as it&#39;s before 9pm and you&#39;re wearing a sombrero - or just
add more exotic combat moves I&#39;m never gonna remember that I
have in a pinch. I was trying to focus on stealth &#39;cos surprise
attacks do ridiculous damage compared to whaling on dudes
head on, it&#39;s the difference between throwing knives at a condom
full of guts and flicking gumballs at a breeze block.
But mandatory combat kept coming up so I looked at the warrior
upgrade path and the first thing was &quot;Gain the ability to hit an
enemy to build up energy, then tap a button to infuse them with
energy and then shoot an arrow at them to do extra damage.&quot;
Anything else I need to do for this process, game? Take down their
names and addresses, perhaps? How about just More Damage?
Or a standard melee attack that doesn&#39;t look like we&#39;re trying to
forcefully eject our own spine? So Horizon Forbidden West wasn&#39;t
the best. The highest praise I could offer is that its world offers
frequently quite spectacular visuals somewhere behind all the
GUIs and objective markers and omnipresent tutorial text that
seems eternally worried I&#39;ll forget where the quick berry refill
button is. I note the visual spectacle gets brought up a lot in other
people&#39;s positive reviews, and to those people I would like to pose
a small question: Have you ever tried pressing on your eyelids? If
some pretty shapes and colours really can sell the experience for
you then you might save a bit of money in future if you just sat on
the couch pressing on your eyelids. Also you can add the
experience of listening to Horizon&#39;s dialogue by doing it while
pouring cold porridge down your ears.
*OUTRO MUSIC*
This video was made possible by...
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
